metadata.title: Mechanical performance, pore structure and micro-structural characteristics of graphene oxide nano platelets reinforced cement

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Mechanical performance, pore structure and micro-structural characteristics of graphene oxide nano platelets reinforced cement
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.02.021 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail address: mmahmoud7@gmail.com (M.M. Mokhtar).
M.M. Mokhtar a,⇑, S.A. Abo-El-Enein b, M.Y. Hassaan c, M.S. Morsy a, M.H. Khalil a aHousing and Building Research Center, HBRC, Building Physics Institute, Cairo, Egypt bChemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Cairo, Egypt cPhysics Department, Faculty of Science, Al Azhar University, Cairo, Egypt
h i g h l i g h t s
GONPs significantly enhanced the mechanical strength of OPC pastes. An enhancement in tensile strength by 41% was achieved at 0.03 wt% GONPs. GONPs considerably modified the pore structure of the cement pastes.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 2 November 2016 Received in revised form 5 January 2017 Accepted 7 February 2017
Keywords: Graphene oxidenanoplatelets Cement paste Mechanical strength Pore structure Thermal analysis Microstructure
a b s t r a c t
Graphene oxide nanoplatelets (GONPs) have unique physical properties that make them effective reinforcing materials. The attractive properties of graphene oxide have led to enhance the graphenepolymer nanocomposites. However, limited studies have been performed on using graphene oxide in cementitious nano composites. This article investigates the effect of GONPs reinforcement on mechanical properties, pore size distribution and the micro-structural characteristics of the hardened cement composites. GONPs were added at different percentages of 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04 and 0.05 wt% of cement. Compressive and indirect tensile strengths were determined at 28 days of hydration. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were used for studying the phase composition, the pore size distribution was studied using nitrogen adsorption at 77.35K technique and the microstructure was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Results revealed that, considerable enhancements in both compressive and indirect tensile strengths by about 13 and 41% have been achieved by incorporating GONPs into cement matrix by about 0.02 and 0.03%, respectively. The integration of GONPs into cement has significantly reduced the pore size of the GONPs-modified cement pastes and led to a considerable improvement in the microstructure, with a consequent improvement in the mechanical properties of these composites.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Cementitious materials are the most widely utilized for many decades for different sorts of structures [1]. Although; cement based materials are used over a wide range of a structural applications, they are brittle and possess poor tensile strength. The brittleness of cement structures comes from the inferior characteristics of the cement pastes in the hardened state [2]. Enhancing the strength of cement materials generally can be achieved by using reinforcing microfibers, such as steel fibers [3], carbon fibers [4] polymeric fibers [5,6] and natural fibers [7]. These reinforcing
materials can greatly improve the strength characteristics as a whole and increase the stress at which cement starts to crack, i.e. they delay the crack growth in the cementitious matrix however do not inhibit the crack formation [8].
Nowadays, nanotechnology (NT) has provided nano-scale particles/fibers; including, nano silica (NS), carbon nano tubes (CNTs) and nano graphene oxide (NGO); these might be utilized as reinforcements to inhibit the formation and delay the propagation of micro cracks. The use of nano fibers for improving the mechanical performance of cementitious materials are found to be more efficient than ordinary steel fibers (at millimeter scale) as they help in restricting cracks before they develop into micro cracks. NS [9–14] and nano metakaoline were found to enhance the mechanical performance of cement-based materials [15–20].
Nowadays, great attention was paid to the graphene oxide nanoplatelets (GONPs) being the most beneficial nano reinforcing materials. It is an oxide-functionalized graphene and belongs to the hydrophilic materials, evidently, GO was utilized as a surfactant for many organic ingredients in water [21]. GO is characterized by high degree of dispersion in water and various solvents, due to the presence of oxygenated function groups. This favors its use as a nano reinforcement in different matrices like polymer, ceramic or cement for improving their mechanical performance [22].
The characteristics of GO composites were studied by some researchers; the introduction of GONPs by 0.05 wt% of cement has increased the compressive strength considerably by 15–33%; in addition, an enhancement of about 41–59% has been achieved in the flexural strength [2], the incorporation of GONPs by 0.03 wt% of cement can enhance the compressive strength of GOcement composite and tensile strength by more than 40%; also the total porosity (TP) of cement paste decreased [23]. When GO was added to plain cement and cement mortar at different percentages 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04 and 0.05 wt% of cement, significant improvements in the flexural and compressive strengths of the hardened cement pastes by about 90.5 and 40.4% have been attained at 28 days of hydration, respectively. The flexural and compressive strengths of cement mortar modified with GO at ratios of 0.01, 0.03 and 0.06% increased by 70.5 and 24.4 wt% after 28 days of hydration, respectively [24]. Incorporating the reduced graphene oxide (RGO) into geopolymers at concentrations of 0.00, 0.10, 0.35 and 0.50% by weight has improved the microstructure and resulted in pore free condensed composites with enhanced mechanical performance, previous work reported an enhancement in flexural strength and Young’s modulus by 134 and 376%, respectively [25].
It was found from the literature survey that, there are many conflicts regarding the development of GONPs reinforced cement especially in the GO incorporation ratios and the percentages of enhancements achieved. The main issue to be addressed in this work is to add an extended study to investigate the role of GO in enhancing the properties of hydrated cement by using different analytical techniques.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation and characterization of GONPS
sections.text:
GONPs were synthesized according to the modified Hummer’s technique [26]. Typically, add 1 g of graphite + 0.5 g of NaNO3 in a flask, then add 50 ml of H2SO4 (98%) under constant stirring at 5 C for 1 h, after that, add gradually 3 g of KMnO4 (1 g every 15 min.) taking into consideration that, the temperature of the
solution have to be less 20 C to avoid overheating and explosion. Dilute the solution by slowly adding100 ml warm distilled water, and then treat the solution with 3 ml of 30% H2O2 solution and 100 ml of distilled water to be sure that, KMnO4 is completely reacted. After that, wash the mixture with HCl and water, respectively, finally filtrate and dry to get the final product (GO).
The obtained material was examined by HRTEM to confirm the formation of GONPs and to investigate their morphology. The HRTEM images presented in Fig. 1(A, B) displayed the formation of transparent particles consisting of ultrathin layers with thickness less than 100 nm. The prepared GONPs surface appears as a wrinkled paper that may be due to the strong acid treatment and the high aspect ratio. Yang et al. (2011) explained the wrinkle appearance of GO sheets; that was caused by high aspect ratio (i.e) the GO sheet has several hundred nanometers of length compared to just several nanometers of thickness [27]. As seen also, GONPs appeared in the form of stacked / non-exfoliated thin sheets [28].
Fig. 2 shows the Raman shifts for graphite and GO. There are two main Raman shifts characterizing carbon nano materials ranged from 1200 to 1700 cm 1. In this context, the first band at 1604 cm 1 can be attributed to the graphite mode (G band). While, the second band at 1363 cm 1 attributed to diamondoid mode (D band) [29]. An increase in the intensity of D band in GONPs spectrum over than that of a graphite which is observed at 1350 cm 1 may be due to the amorphization of graphite lattice that is arising from the transformation of some in-plane
of GO.
SP2 carbons in crystalline domain into disordered tetrahedral SP3 carbons in amorphous domain [30] it was also observed that G band becomes broaden and blue shifted about 21 cm 1 to be 1604 cm 1, this can be explained by the reduction in size of the in-plane SP2 domains which is caused by the strong oxidation of graphite [31]. We can measure the quality of graphitization by calculating the ratio between intensity of D band and that of G band (ID/IG). In comparison with graphite, the ID / IG was observed to increase from 0.18 for graphite to be 1.08 for GONPs this was due to the increase of disordered structure in graphite arised from different functional groups present in the structure.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of cement composites
sections.text:
In this investigation, six mixes of cement-GONPs composites were studied. GONPs were added to ordinary Portland cement (OPC) by different ratios 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04 and 0.05% by weight of cement. Firstly the as prepared GONPs were dispersed in the mixing water through ultrasonication process (at 250 Watt and frequency of 20 KHz) for 20 min. to be sure of good dispersion and to prevent agglomeration of GONPs. Now the mixing water with GO sheets dispersed in it can be added to cement to prepare the cement composites. The chemical composition of the used OPC is presented in Table 1, while the mix composition was presented in Table 2. Due to the hydrophilic nature of GONPs, the W/C ratio was observed to increase with increasing GONPs ratio, as shown in Table 2.
The cement composite pastes were casted into 20 mm cubes for compressive strength test. In order to expel any contained air bubbles the molds were vibrated for 1 min. The fresh pastes were kept in their molds at 100% relative humidity for 24 h, and then the samples are demolded and cured under tap water for 27 days [2].
Table 2 Mix design of cement–nano GO composites.
Mix designation OPC, (%) GONPs, (%) W/C ratio
F0 100 0 0.2500 F1 0.01 0.2830 F2 0.02 0.2925 F3 0.03 0.3000 F4 0.04 0.3025 F5 0.05 0.3075

sections.heading: 3.1. Compressive strength
sections.text: The Compressive strength of the samples was performed after 2, 7, 14 and 28 days of hydration on 20 mm cubic specimens as per a previous study for cement pastes [32] using RMU testing equipment hosted in HBRC, 57-2400 BERGAMO ITALY using loading rate 0.5 kn/sec. with a maximum force 1500 kn. Three specimens at each age were tested and the average compressive strength was calculated.

sections.heading: 3.2. Indirect tensile strength
sections.text:
The indirect tensile strength of hardened cement paste can be determined by the splitting test [33]. In this test a load is applied along the center of two opposed faces of a cube by means of narrow steel strips. Figs. 3 (a, b) show photos of the tested samples and the experimental setup of this test. A set of three cubes were used for the determination of the indirect tensile strength at 28 days of curing using RMU Testing equipment hosted in HBRC, 57-2400 BERGAMO ITALY using loading rate 0.16 kn/sec. with a maximum force 1500 kn.
The tensile stress which is created in the plane between the line loads that splits the cube can be calculated from the formula:
Ts ¼ 2P=pL2
Where: Ts is the tensile strength (MPa), P is the load at failure (N) and L is the edge length of the cube (mm).

sections.heading: 3.3. SEM
sections.text: The microstructure of the freshly fractured surface of the specimens was examined using scanning electron microscope (SEM Jeol 6360, Japan).

sections.heading: 3.4. X-ray diffraction (XRD)
sections.text:
The XRD analysis was performed by using X’Pert Pro MPD PW 3040/60 X-ray (PANalytical) diffractometer equipped with monochromatic Cu-Ka radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. The used XRD apparatus was a continuous mode and used for collecting data in the 2h range from 5 to 50 at a scanning speed of 2 /min.
ration of the tensile strength.

sections.heading: 3.5. Thermal analysis
sections.text: Thermogravimetric analyses of the samples were conducted using a DSC-TGA thermal analyzer (STD-Q600, USA) instrument from 25 C up to 1000 C at a heating rate of 10 C/min. The sample chamber was purged with nitrogen gas at a flow rate of 100 ml/ min.

sections.heading: 3.6. Pore structure and surface area
sections.text: The Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were obtained for the hardened pastes of GO blended cement composites at 77.35K using a NOVA2000e (Quantachrome, USA) instrument. The pore-size distribution curves were obtained using non local density function theory (NLDFT) kernel.

sections.heading: 4.1. Compressive strength
sections.text: Fig. 4 shows the compressive strength results of the cured OPC pastes with different GONPs additions. Evidently, the compressive strength of the hardened specimens at each curing age increase with increasing GONPs percentage up to 0.02%, by further increase weight of GONPs dosage in OPC leads to a gradual decrease in the compressive strength. As shown in this figure, specimens containing 0.02 wt% GONPs exhibited about 13% increase in compressive strength compared with that of the control OPC samples, that can be explained by improvement in mechanical interlocking caused by wrinkled appearance of GO sheets, strong interaction between cracks and GONPs due to the 2Dsheet-like structure and high aspect ratio, enhancement of the hydration process and formation of strong interfacial forces arised from chemical interactions between oxygenated functional groups and hydration products [2] and the reduction of the pore structure in cement composite [23]. Also the gradual decrease may be interpreted by the agglomeration of the GONPs that result in difficulty to achieve uniform distribution of GONPs throughout the cement matrix.

sections.heading: 4.2. Indirect tensile strength
sections.text:
Fig. 5 demonstrates the indirect tensile strength of cement pastes reinforced with different additions of GONPs. The indirect tensile strength of the hardened specimens at each curing
age increase with increasing GONPs dosage up to 0.03%; any further increase in GONPs dosage leads to a gradual decrease in the indirect tensile strength. As shown in Fig. 5 the hardened specimens containing 0.03 wt% GONPs exhibited about 41% increase in indirect tensile strength compared with that of the control (OPC) samples, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between cracks and GONPs because of 2D structure and high aspect ratio, while the gradual decrease may be attributed to the agglomeration of the GONPs that resulted in difficulty to achieve uniform distribution of GONPs throughout the cement matrix and may be caused the sliding of the GONPs over each other.

sections.heading: 4.3. Pore structure analysis
sections.text:
The hardened cement paste is composed of the solid part of hydrated cement and the pores. There are different reasons for the presence of pores in the hardened cement paste among them the excess water and air. These pores affect the strength, durability and shrinkage. In this study, the pore sizes and their distribution was determined by nitrogen adsorption technique. There are four main pore size distribution categories in cement paste: pores of size >1000 nm are called large pores, capillary pores are of size between 100 and 1000 nm, meso-pores or transitional pores have size ranges from 10 to 100 nm and finally the gel pores have size <10 nm. Based on this classification, the pores in our samples are mainly meso-pores and gel pores. Moreover, macroscopic pores (>50 nm) contribute to permeability and strength, while microscopic pores (<50 nm) may affect the dry shrinkage and creep [34,35].
Results of Fig. 6 indicate that, the addition of GONPs can efficiently improve the pore structure, through reducing the pore size and making the cement paste more compact. The GONPs concentration of 0.02 wt% yielded the lowest intensity in the pore size distribution and consequently, the highest compressive strength values; the intensity of the peak is an indication for the number of pores having the transitional pore size (meso-pores) and the location of the peak represents the sizes of these pores. Therefore, the addition of 0.02% GONPs resulted in a decrease in the number of transitional pores (meso-pores). Obviously the GONPs addition into the cement paste resulted in a modification in the pore structure of the hardened OPC– GONPs composites with a maximum modification by using 0.02% of GONPs, and this may explain the reinforcing action mechanism of GONPs, including both chemical and physical contributions.

sections.heading: 4.4. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
The contents of calcium hydroxide (CH) in the plain (OPC) and GONPs-reinforced cement pastes were detected using thermogravimetric analysis technique (TGA) at 28 days of curing. The results are also presented as derivative thermogravimetric (DTG) curves in order to identify the detected phases. The peak located at about 140 C represents nearly amorphous C-S-H while, the peak appeared at about 190 C represents micro crystalline part of C-S-H and the peaks appeared at 640 and 690 C are due to the decomposition of amorphous and crystalline CaCO3, respectively. While, CH was detected at 415–475 C [36]. As it can be seen that, the peak characterizing CH phase gets sharper with the addition of GONPs which indicates that, CH phases of the GONPsreinforced cement pastes are well crystallized as compared with the plain paste, The figure also shows a low decrease in C-S-H peak and a slow increase in CaCO3 peaks which may be due to the reaction of –COOH group with a part of CH leading the formation of calcium carboaluminate hydrate. In DTA curves it was observed that the peak characterizing carbonation increased with increasing GONPs addition, which is confirmed with the XRD results. The DTG-thermograms are presented in Fig. 7. Furthermore, all the steps characterizing the CH phases of the prepared blended mixes are shifted relative to the plain mix (without GONPs) which confirms the high degree of thermal stability of the hydration products, because of the GONPs reinforcing effect; the TGAthermograms are shown in Fig. 8.
The amount of CH was calculated according to the following equation:
CH% ¼ WLCHð%Þ MWCH=MWH
Where, WLCH; the percent weight loss of calcium hydroxide (CH), MWCH; the molecular weight of CH, MWH; the molecular weight of H2O.
Fig. 9 presents the CH amount of the plain (OPC) and GONPsreinforced cement pastes; evidently, the plain (OPC) paste contains about 12% CH. The addition of GONPs up to 0.02% has reduced the CH content; because, the GONPs favor the formation of calcium carboaluminate hydrates, 3CaO Al2O3 CaCO3 11H2O, due to their high chemical reactivity. Also it can be seen that, with increasing GO content over 0.02 wt%, the CH starts to increase again although its amount in the all blended mixes still less than the plain composite which may be attributed to difficulty to achieve uniform distribution of GONPs throughout the cement matrix or a sort of GONPs agglomeration in the composites having more than 0.02% GONPs.

sections.heading: 4.5. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis
sections.text: Fig. 10 shows the XRD patterns of the cement composites modified with different GONPs additions after 28 days of curing. The phases detected are the usual cement hydrates as CSH, CH and calcium carboaluminate hydrate [37]. Furthermore, the increase of calcium carboaluminate hydrate created through the reaction of the –COOH functional groups with C3A phase. The increase of calcium carboaluminate hydrated phase may contribute to enhanced durability of the hardened cement pastes.

sections.heading: 4.6. Morphology and microstructure
sections.text:
The mechanical properties of cementatious materials are determined by their microstructure characteristics. In order to
A
C
determine the reasons of mechanical strength improvements and to get visual evidence of the microstructural characteristics responsible for these improvements, the morphology and microstructure was performed for the GONPs cement composites as presented in Fig. 11. The SEM micrograph of plain mix (OPC) revealed non-uniform distribution of the hydrated phases; furthermore, macro pores and micro cracks are observed as shown in Fig. 11A. The addition of GONPs has generally modified the microstructure and resulted in more uniform and compact structure as they cause bridging (2D reinforcement) between cement hydrates as presented in Fig. 11 (B–F). Evidently, the microstructure of the hardened specimens made of OPC–GONPs composites displayed the formation of interlocking fibers and wrinkled foils of CSH; so the number of binding centers in the hardened specimens increased leading to an increase in the hydraulic properties of these specimens. The microstructure obtained for the specimens made until 0.02% addition of GONPs appeared to have larger points of contact in C-S-H, leading to the maximum improvement of the mechanical properties; this provides a strongly hydraulic structure having an increase in the total contents of binding centers. Furthermore, Nucleation of hydration products on nanoparticles further promotes and accelerates cement hydration and results in enhanced strength [38,39].
B
D
F
composites modified by different additions of GONPs: (A) F0, (B) F1, (C) F2, (D) F3, (E)

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
The influence of GONPs dosage on the microstructural characteristics, mechanical performance and pore structure of cement composites were investigated. The results indicated that:
In contrast to many previous studies it can be concluded that, small ratios of GONPs about 0.02–0.03% can enhance the physico-mechanical characteristics of hardened OPC–GONPs composite pastes. The addition of GONPs in cement paste significantly increases the compressive and indirect tensile strengths. The addition of 0.02% GONPs increased the compressive strength by about 13%. While the indirect tensile strength was increased by 41% at 0.03 wt% of GONPs than the control (OPC) paste. GONPs modified the pore structure, through reducing the number of pore and making the cement paste more compact and strongly hydraulic. GONPs increase the degree of thermal stability of the hydration products especially of CH phase, due to the GONPs reinforcing effect, also the CH content decreased by the addition of GONPs. GONPs promote the hydration reaction of cement, improving the nucleation and growth of hydrated products and enhance the hydration procedure.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: We are grateful to Housing and Building Research Center (HBRC), Physics department of Al Azhar University, Dr. Sherif A. El-Khodary and Dr. Hamada Shoukry for their help in conducting this study.

02 wt% GONPs exhibited about 13% increase in compressive strength compared with that of the control OPC samples, that can be explained by improvement in mechanical interlocking caused by wrinkled appearance of GO sheets, strong interaction between cracks and GONPs due to the 2Dsheet-like structure and high aspect ratio, enhancement of the hydration process and formation of strong interfacial forces arised from chemical interactions between oxygenated functional groups and hydration products [2] and the reduction of the pore structure in cement composite [23].

metadata.abstractText: Graphene oxide nanoplatelets (GONPs) have unique physical properties that make them effective reinforcing materials. The attractive properties of graphene oxide have led to enhance the graphenepolymer nanocomposites. However, limited studies have been performed on using graphene oxide in cementitious nano composites. This article investigates the effect of GONPs reinforcement on mechanical properties, pore size distribution and the micro-structural characteristics of the hardened cement composites. GONPs were added at different percentages of 0, 0.01, 0.02, 0.03, 0.04 and 0.05 wt% of cement. Compressive and indirect tensile strengths were determined at 28 days of hydration. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were used for studying the phase composition, the pore size distribution was studied using nitrogen adsorption at 77.35K technique and the microstructure was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Results revealed that, considerable enhancements in both compressive and indirect tensile strengths by about 13 and 41% have been achieved by incorporating GONPs into cement matrix by about 0.02 and 0.03%, respectively. The integration of GONPs into cement has significantly reduced the pore size of the GONPs-modified cement pastes and led to a considerable improvement in the microstructure, with a consequent improvement in the mechanical properties of these composites. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
